Measure and record weight:
∙ A pregnant woman’s weight should be taken at each visit. The
weight taken during the first visit/registration should be treated
as the baseline weight.(Annexure 2)
∙ Normally, a woman should gain 9-11 kg during her pregnancy.
Ideally after the first trimester, a pregnant woman gains around
2 kg every month.
∙ An inadequate dietary intake can be suspected if the woman
gains less than 2 kg per month. She needs to be put on food
supplementation and counselled for adequate dietary intake.
Lowweight gain usually leads to Intrauterine Growth Retardation
(IUGR) and results in the birth of a baby with a low birth weight.
∙ Excessive weight gain (more than 3 kg in a month) should raise
suspicion of preeclampsia, twins (multiple pregnancy) or diabetes. Take the woman’s blood pressure and test
her urine for proteinuria or sugar. If her blood pressure is high, i.e., more than 140/90 mmHg, and her urine
has proteins or sugar, refer her to the PHC-Medical Officer.

sources.content:
gain (see further information in points below).
• A healthy lifestyle includes aerobic physical activity and strength-conditioning exercise aimed at
maintaining a good level of fitness throughout pregnancy, without trying to reach peak fitness level or
train for athletic competition. Women should choose activities with minimal risk of loss of balance and
fetal trauma (42).
• Most normal gestational weight gain occurs after 20 weeks of gestation and the definition of “normal” is
subject to regional variations, but should take into consideration pre-pregnant body mass index (BMI).
According to the Institute of Medicine classification (43), women who are underweight at the start of
pregnancy (i.e. BMI <18.5kg/ m2) should aim to gain 12.5–18kg, women who are normal weight at the
start of pregnancy (i.e. BMI 18.5–24.9kg/ m2) should aim to gain 11.5–16kg, overweight women (i.e. BMI
25–29.9k g /m2) should aim to gain 7–11.5kg, and obese women(i.e. BMI >30kg/ m2) should aim to gain
5–9kg.

question_original: Pragnancy me mango 🥭 kitna mntra me kha skti hu
question_translated: Translation: How many months into pregnancy can I eat mangoes?
answer:
Based on the provided medical guidelines, mangoes, which are rich in Vitamin A, are specifically mentioned as part of the diet in the 6th month of pregnancy. The guidelines suggest including mango among other Vitamin A rich foods such as spinach, methi, carrot, pumpkin, milk, eggs, and tomato in your meals and snacks daily during this month.

Therefore, you can safely consume mangoes starting from the 6th month of pregnancy, as per the guidelines provided.

sources.content:
Mid-day snack
∙ Along with major meals a pregnant woman should consume at least 2-3 healthy mid-day snacks.
∙ One to two carbohydrate serving can be taken in mid-day snack.  
67
∙ A mother should maintain 2-3 hours gap with major meal when taking mid-day snack.
∙ Eating fried foods or junk foods or food with high amount of free sugars should be avoided.
∙ Some options for snack could be murmura chat, sprouts, vegetable dalia, vegetable poha, idli, vegetable
uttapam, besanchilla with low amount of oil etc.
General tips
∙ Fried foods should be avoided;the mother should rather steam, boil or sauté food in a non-stick pan.
∙ Whole fruits should be preferred over juices.
∙ Prefer fish or chicken over red or organ meat.
∙ Fibre should be increased in the diet by including salad, beans, non-starchy vegetables, whole fruit, whole
grain cereals, whole pulses.
∙ A mother should drink water, buttermilk, soups, soy milk and other unsweetened healthy beverages
instead of soda or fruit juice.  
68

sources.content:
Page 7 of 36  
In a systematic review  (192 studies and over 64,000 pregnant and recently PW with
suspected or confirmed COVID-19) by Allotey J et al7, pregnant and recently pregnant women
with Covid-19 attending or admitted to the hospitals for any reason are less likely to manifest
symptoms such as fever, dyspnoea, and myalgia, and are more likely to be admitted to the
intensive care unit or needing invasive ventilation than non -pregnant women o f
reproductive age. Pregnant women with covid-19 versus without covid-19 are more likely to
deliver preterm and could have an increased risk of maternal death and of being admitted
to the intensive care unit.
Effect on the Foetus
• Risk of miscarriage - The frequency of miscarriage does not appear to be increased, but
data on first and second trimester infections are limited.
• Congenital anomalies -There are no reports of any increased risk of congenital anomalies
with COVID-19 infection.

A) A baby is brought to you with yellow skin on the palms of his/her hands and on the soles
of his/her feet.  He/She is 30 hours old. Describe how will you treat this baby?
• Jaundice :
o Yellow skin on face and only <24 hours old.
o Yellow palms and soles and >24 hours old.
• Management :
o Refer baby urgently to hospital.
o Encourage breastfeeding on the way.
o If  feeding difficulty, give expressed breast milk by cup/katori.
B) What are signs of a sick baby?
• Fast breathing (more than 60 breaths per minute).
• Slow breathing (less than 30 breaths per minute).
• Severe chest in-drawing
• Grunting.
• Convulsions.
• Floppy or stiff.
• Fever (temperature >38ºC).
• Temperature <35ºC or not rising after rewarming.
• Umbilicus draining pus or umbilical redness extending to skin.
• More than 10 skin pustules or bullae, or swelling, redness, hardness of  skin.
• Bleeding from stump or cord.
• Pallor.
Management :
• Give first dose of IM antibiotics (as per IMNCI protocols).

question_original: What danger signs can I look out for during my pregnancy
question_translated: What danger signs should I be aware of during my pregnancy?
answer:
During your pregnancy, it is crucial to be aware of certain danger signs that may indicate serious complications. Based on the provided medical guidelines, here are the key danger signs you should monitor and act upon immediately by seeking medical help:

1. **Excessive swelling in the feet and puffiness on the face.**
2. **Difficulty in breathing.**
3. **Severe pain and burning sensation during urination.**
4. **Repeated fever during pregnancy or within one month of delivery.**
5. **Severe stomach ache.**
6. **Bleeding from the vagina.**
7. **Bursting of the water bag prior to delivery.**
8. **Headache, blurring of vision, convulsions.**
9. **Not being able to feel the baby’s movement inside the womb.**

Additional signs include:
- **Generalized weakness, easy fatigability, and breathlessness.**
- **High-grade fever or any medical illness.**
- **Excessive nausea and vomiting.**
- **Leaking per vaginum before the onset of labor.**
- **High blood pressure detected after delivery/abortion.**

These signs are indicators of potential complications that could affect both your health and the baby’s health. Immediate contact with a healthcare provider or visiting a Primary Health Center (PHC)/First Referral Unit (FRU) is advised if any of these signs are observed.

question_translated: Translation: If a child has a severe cold, how should we manage it?
answer:
Based on the provided medical context, for managing a severe cold in a child, the following steps can be recommended:

1. **Symptomatic Treatment for Fever, Running Nose, and Cough**: This includes the use of medications to reduce fever and alleviate symptoms. For fever, Tab. Paracetamol 650 mg can be given up to four times a day. If the fever is not controlled with this, consider other drugs like NSAIDs (Tab. Naproxen 250 mg twice a day).

2. **Warm Water Gargles and Steam Inhalation**: These can be performed twice a day to help relieve a cough and congestion.

3. **Inhalational Budesonide**: If there is a persistent cough or fever beyond 5 days of illness, Inhalational Budesonide can be administered via DPI/MDI with Spacer at a dose of 800 mcg BD for 5 to 7 days.

These recommendations are based on the symptomatic treatment guidelines provided in the context. It is important to monitor the child's temperature, heart rate, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) regularly, as indicated in the self-monitoring chart (Figure 6) provided in the context. If symptoms worsen or do not improve, consider seeking further medical advice or inpatient management, especially for high-risk patients.

question_original: Kya pregnancy m bleeding hoti h kya yeh normal h
question_translated: Translation: Does bleeding occur during pregnancy, and is it normal?
answer:
Yes, bleeding can occur during pregnancy, but it is not always normal and should be evaluated by a healthcare provider. According to the guidelines provided in the context:

1. **Early Pregnancy (before 20 weeks)**: Bleeding could be due to various reasons such as a threatened or spontaneous abortion, an ectopic pregnancy, or a hydatidiform mole. 
   - **Threatened abortion**: The management might include activity restriction, but no medication is specifically required.
   - **Incomplete abortion**: If it occurs up to 12 weeks, manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) is recommended to evacuate the uterus. If bleeding does not stop or the woman is in shock, intravenous fluids should be administered rapidly, and the woman should be referred to a medical officer with a referral slip.

2. **Late Pregnancy (after 20 weeks)**: Bleeding during the second half of pregnancy should be considered as due to placenta previa unless proven otherwise, and vaginal examination is contraindicated as it may provoke heavy bleeding.

It is important to seek medical attention if bleeding occurs during pregnancy to determine the cause and appropriate management.

question_original: mujhe thyroid h to kya isse bhi breast milk pe asar hota h
question_translated: Translation: I have thyroid issues; does it also affect breast milk?
answer:
The provided medical guidelines do not specifically address the direct impact of thyroid issues on breast milk composition or production. However, it is known from general medical knowledge that thyroid hormones can influence lactation and milk supply indirectly. Thyroid dysfunction can affect overall energy levels, metabolism, and possibly the hormonal balance necessary for milk production. 

For a more specific and detailed understanding of how thyroid issues might affect breastfeeding, it would be advisable to consult with a healthcare provider who can offer guidance based on a comprehensive assessment of the individual's health status and thyroid function.

Look for Symptoms of thyroid dysfunction or the presence of goitre:
Uncontrolled hypothyroidism during pregnancy can lead to preeclampsia, anaemia, miscarriage, low birth weight
baby, stillbirth, and rarely congestive heart failure.
∙ Look for the symptoms of hypothyroidism: Feeling tired, unable to stand cold temperatures, hoarse voice,
swelling of the face, weight gain, constipation, skin and hair changes, including dry skin and loss of eyebrows,
carpal tunnel syndrome (hand tingling or pain), slow heart rate, muscle cramps and irregular menstrual
periods.
∙ Routine screening for hypothyroidism during pregnancy is not recommended. A pregnant woman with
symptoms of hypothyroidism, a history of hypothyroidism, or with other endocrine system conditions or
high-risk pregnant woman should be screened for hypothyroidism.
∙ ASHA/ANM will identify pregnant women at risk for hypothyroidism and refer to SHC-HWC and counsel

question_original: What food is better for proper development of the baby?
question_translated: What food is better for proper development of the baby?
answer:
For the proper development of the baby, it is important to include a variety of foods in the diet that are rich in essential nutrients. According to the provided medical guidelines, the following foods are recommended:

1. **Proteins**: Important for growth and development. Sources include meat, egg, fish, chicken, paneer, milk and other milk products, combined grains, seeds, nuts, and soya beans.

2. **Iron**: Necessary for blood formation and overall growth. Rich sources include green leafy vegetables, whole grains, cereals, dry fruits, nuts, meat, and jaggery.

3. **Calcium**: Essential for the baby's bone development. Sources include milk, milk products, sesame seeds, almonds, soya milk, turnip, and egg.

4. **Vitamins**: 
   - **Vitamin A**: Found in orange and dark green vegetables, citrus fruits, apple, tomato, amla, vegetables, meat, fish, eggs, sunlight, milk and milk products, soya products.
   - **Folate**: Critical for the development of the baby's brain and spinal cord. Sources include catla fish, moth beans, kidney beans, soybean, spinach, sem ki phali, sarson ka saag, and chicken liver.

5. **Fats**: Necessary for energy and supporting the baby's growth. Healthy sources include butter, ghee, oils, and nuts.

The guidelines also emphasize the importance of consuming double fortified salt (iodine and iron), as iodine is critical for the baby’s brain development and iron is necessary for blood formation.

It is also recommended to maintain a balanced diet with at least 3 main meals and 2 nutritious snacks daily to meet increased nutrient requirements for proper growth and development of the baby.

These recommendations are based on the context provided from the medical guidelines and literature.

question_translated: Translation: It has been 2.5 months since I became pregnant, but I am not experiencing any vomiting or anything else.
answer:
आपके प्रश्न के अनुसार, आपको गर्भावस्था के 2.5 महीने हो चुके हैं और आपको उल्टी या कोई अन्य लक्षण नहीं हो रहे हैं। यह जानकारी देते हुए कि गर्भावस्था के दौरान उल्टी और मतली लगभग 70% गर्भवती महिलाओं को होती है और आमतौर पर पहली तिमाही में होती है, यह भी संभव है कि कुछ महिलाओं को ये लक्षण न हों। इसलिए, यदि आपको उल्टी नहीं हो रही है, तो यह असामान्य नहीं है और इसे चिंता का विषय नहीं माना जाना चाहिए।

हालांकि, यदि आपको कोई अन्य लक्षण या चिंताएँ हों, तो आपको अपने स्वास्थ्य प्रदाता से संपर्क करना चाहिए। यह सुनिश्चित करने के लिए कि आपकी गर्भावस्था सामान्य रूप से प्रगति कर रही है, नियमित रूप से अपनी गर्भावस्था की जांच करवाना महत्वपूर्ण है।

sources.content:
physiological symptoms
Background
Women’s bodies undergo substantial changes
during pregnancy, which are brought about by both
hormonal and mechanical effects. These changes lead
to a variety of common symptoms – including nausea
and vomiting, low back and pelvic pain, heartburn,
varicose veins, constipation and leg cramps – that in
some women cause severe discomfort and negatively
affects their pregnancy experience. In general,
symptoms associated with mechanical effects, e.g.
pelvic pain, heartburn and varicose veins, often
worsen as pregnancy progresses.
Symptoms of nausea and vomiting are experienced
by approximately 70% of pregnant women and
usually occur in the first trimester of pregnancy
(156); however, approximately 20% of women may
experience nausea and vomiting beyond 20weeks of
gestation (157). Low back and pelvic pain is estimated
to occur in half of pregnant women, 8% of whom
experience severe disability (158). Symptoms of
heartburn occur in two thirds of pregnant women,

sources.content:
Normal symptoms during pregnancy – Nausea and vomiting, heartburn, constipation, and increased
frequency of urination. These symptoms may cause discomfort to the woman.
Examine symptoms of complications – Fever, persistent vomiting with dehydration, palpitations,
tiredness, breathlessness at rest/on mild exertion, generalised swelling of body/facial puffiness, severe
headache and/or blurring of vision, passing smaller amount of urine or burning micturition, leaking or bleeding
per vagina, abnormal vaginal discharge/itching, high blood pressure detected in ANC, leaking for more than
12 hours without labour pain and decreased or absent foetal movements and presence of goitre.
3. Take Obstetric History– It is essential to ask the woman about her previous pregnancies or obstetric
history to determine if there were any complications in previous pregnancies. Some complications may recur
during the present pregnancy. Obtain the following information while taking the obstetric history:
